element_texts.text:
Dec. 15, 1977
YOU WERE EXPECTING
A PARTRIDGE
IN A PEAR TREE?
Forget it!
Red

[1974]
Jack - The Aug 15 deadline
is fine. I don't know whether
the essay will ever see the
light of day, but I will have
the satisfaction of paying you 
$300 for it. 
more later -
Yrs. Guda

[upper right corner]: Burke, John Gordon [no date]
Dear Jack:
I had hoped to get up Friday and deliver the books to you plus the Anvils. Thursday night I got a terrific case of flu and I have not yet recovered. As I am supposed to venture forth to Albuquerque, New Mexico tomorrow to keep inlaws happy about the Christmas season, I will not be able to get to Moberly until after my return next week.
I am sending along a broadside poem of Mona Van Duyn's "The [ Twins ? ] ".  Won the Borestone Award for 1968, and had a few printed on japanese hand made paper for friends, etc. The poem will also appear in the Dec. magazine whenever it comes out.
Have a lot of news, but  it can wait until after Christmas. Best wishes for etc, . . . . Gordon

April 19th, 1949
                                                                                                                                                                                                     116 1/2 Mason Street
                                                                                                                                                                                                     Polo, Illinois

Mr. Jack Conroy
c/o Max Siegel
55 E. Washington Street
Chicago, Illinois
Dear Mr. Conroy:
Our Polo Women's club is planning it's program for next year. We should like very much to have you as 
our speaker on our literature program - March 14th, 1950 on a Tuesday afternoon. 
Polo is a hundred miles west of Chicago. There are morning trains to Oregon or Dixon - trains back in the 
late afternoon or evening. 
Our usual attendance is around sixty. If you feel you can make the appointment, how much will your charges
be? We would like a list of your preferred subject to choose from - also a list of reading matter to the suggested the club a month 
prior to your talk. 
We shall appreciate a reply from you by May 1, if possible. 
Sincerely,
Marie Busman 
(Mrs. J. B. Busman)

June 8th, 1949
                                                                                                                                                                                             Polo, Illinois

Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 So. Green Street
Chicago 21st, Illinois
Dear Mr. Conroy:
Our Women's Club Committee decided we would like to hear
your talk on  "Humor of the Midwest" on Tuesday afternoon March 14th, 1950.
Your fee of 35.00 plus transportation is also agreeable. After the first of the year, 
I shall write you again and at that time we would like a newspaper cut and material
about you for publication.
Thank you so much.
Sincerely, 
Marie Burman 
(Mrs. Grant B.)

Dear Jack:
This is not to ask you for any money but merely to give you the run down on my museum idea.  Can you send me a list of names of people who could assist us financial or bookwise? Please do. How nice it was to see you and Gladys last week. Let it not be the last time. Please let us keep in close touch. Did you receive the book? Margaret delivers the goods!
All our love
Margaret and Charlie

Nov 1, 1950
Dear Jack --
We got the Writers Round table started somewhat at the Art Center. Thanks to some of the names you sent me. Our next session will be on Sunday  Nov. 19 from 3 to 5 p.m. and I am hoping that you can be present to help comment on some of the new manuscripts that will be read. If you think you can make it -- let me know since we would like to publicize it --
Cordially
Margaret [ Gon? ] Burroughs

[ ou ? ] 4-5523 --

I stay so  busy with this Center, I can't get any writing  wrote!!

3806 South Michigan
Chicago 15, Illinois
Sept. 18, 1954
Dear Jack and family:
You cannot imagine how shocked, hurt and saddened Charles and I were to hear about Tom. We wish to express our deepest consolation to you all. We were very close to Tom and feel a guilty pang that we were not here during the time that he was feeling so despairing. Perhaps we could have talked to him and bolstered his confidence and morale. We will always remember him with fondness. Belatedly as it comes, if there is anything at all that we can do in memory of Tom, please let us know. Please convey our feelings to his wife, whom we did not know as well. I will never forget the pleasant time Tom and I had at the folklore conference.  May we come over and see you sometime at your convenience.
Our best regards
Margaret & Charles Burroughs
Or 3-7972

in pencil  Burroughs, Margaret
letterhead  MARGARET AND CHARLES BURROUGHS,  3806 S. Michigan, Chicago, Illinois

Aug 9, 1956
Dear Jack:
Kindly send me the address of the Gugenheim Foundation. I hope to try + get a year off from teaching by Them. I'll cook up some kind of project having to do with Negro folk lore. Regards to Gladys +hope to see you soon again.
Sincerely, Margaret
Also the address of Yaddo, the writers retreat.

3/29/63
Our dearest, dearest Jack and Gladys:

  Thank you for the copy of "The Disinherited."  It will be a welcome addition to the Library the Museum. And - we will get a chance to read it.  Museum doing fine - a non profit institution -
  But other big things are happening.
  We are helping to create The State

2) 
of Illinois Exhibit for the Centennial to be held at McCormick Place in August & are getting paid by the State of Illinois, Research and article direction.  We must get together soon for we have a lot of things to tell you - so - let us know which Saturday nite, you can receive us.
We have a friend with a car.
So now - we wait to hear from you.
We'll even bring the grog.
Your friends who love you
Margaret & Charlie & Paul
Ke 6-8910

Mr. Jack Conroy 
7027 S. Jeffrey Blvd
Chicago, Ill.
60649

Friend,
Thank you for your order. "Whip Me - Whop Me" will be sent to you about July 1.
Sincerely,
MBurrough

Jan 20, 1968
Dearest Jack & Gladys:
Glad I finally got your address straight. Thanks to your Xmas Card. Just want you to know we think of you both often & do miss not thinking of you in close periphery even tho when you were here we didnt see you near as much as we liked to. There was some sense of security in just knowing that you were as near as our telephone. And now you are off in Moberly -- & Moberly seems to be at a the end of the earth, -- Maybe -- if you will write

and tell us how we get there by car -- & if its possible to do on a weekend -- Chas & I will come & see you since we went into debt & got a car. So will you let us know what roads etc. we take -- We want to see you both in the worst way. We love you both --
Love --
Margaret & Charlie

1
[letterhead:]  Museum of African American History 3806 South Michigan Avenue Chicago, Illinois 60653 KE 6-8910
[handwritten:] 701 Fisk Ave  Moberly Mo. 65270
10/26/68
Dearest Jack:
How wonderful it was to see you today at the DuSable Celebration! You know -- it made the whole trip up there most meaningful. And you looked so good and all. Retirement seems to agree with you. On the plane back I took time to read your little pamphlet -- "Home to Moberly." It is a beautiful article -- and a wonderful statement about you, yourself, your work and your life and literature. And Jack -- I do agree with you about these young newly black writers -- Leroi Jones, et al. I cannot seem to work up any enthusiasm about the "trash and cuss words" They are

2
putting out under the guise of "black" literature. Charles and I certainly and conclusively reject the "black fascist attitude" -- I wince everytime I hear a black person use the term "hunkie." We cannot condone this -- even at the risk of being called "Integrationist, Negro or White folks lover." You -- and many other non-pigmented peoples have been our closest, dearest, and most trusted allies and friends. We cannot, we will  not, we must not desert you --  for you have never deserted us and you have been in the forefront of speaking and fighting for our rights and the rights of all oppressed and deprived Americans. So -- please know that we love you and Gladys as we

3
loved Tom, of fond memory. We must get together. We have so much to talk about. Our travels in USSR, and us most recently in Africa. Therefore,  there is so much we have to talk about that we will just have to get together in person to talk about it. So -- it seems that since you won't come to Chicago -- Charles and  I will have to manage to get to Moberly -- one of these weekends. In fact, we think we will try and make it out there -- Thanksgiving. Would you please send us road directions as to how to come. And if its O.K. we will come.
Jack & Gladys we love you!
Margaret
(over)
It was so wonderful to see you and Margret Saturday Jack --

Nov. 25, 1968
Dear Jack: and Gladys:
Sorry, cant make it Thanksgiving. I decided to go to Montreal and the Hemispherie Peace Conference & make my voice heard to stop the war. Maybe if the war is stopped we can get other things together. But we will come another week end & will let you know in front. Please send me a road map of Missouri. 
Thanx
Margaret

[letterhead with image:] The Society To Honor Paul Robeson 
Hi My Man,
Margaret says she saw you and you looked good. No use telling you how we missed you and Gladys, but we will probably pickup and come to see you Thanksgiving if that is alright by you.
Love Charlie

Bole, No. Ghana
July 29
Dear Jack & Gladys:
A couple of months ago, we were n Moberly.  Now we are 6000 miles away in a little village in Northern Ghana. Contrary to what we have heard, haven't seen any wild animals yet --  maybe a couple of monkeys But thats all --
Love to you both
Margaret & Charlie

Air letter envelope
Gladys & John Conroy
701 Fiske Ave
Moberley, Mo.  U.S.A.
M & C Burroughs
A.F.A.S.  Univ. of Ghana, Legon
Accra, Ghana

April 22, 1972

Jach and Gladys:
Dear Mr and Mrs. Conroy: 
As a result of your generosity, the Archibald Motley purse 
amounted to $700.
He was so delighted!
Again, thank you.
Love - Sincerely,
Margaret
National Conf. of Artists

(left side)
6/12
Dear Jack:
HAPPY PAPPY DAY!
Hi Gladys!
Love –
Margret and Charlie
(right side)
MR. JACK CONROY
701 FISK AVE. 
MOBERLY, MO

4/15/73
Dearest Jack:
How are you and Gladys? Fine, I hope. I am getting together another little volume of my poems. May I quote the introduction that you wrote in "Unrest: The Rebel Poets Anthology" 1929. I like that statement.
Is that OK? Let me know. What's with you guys? Do you ever come into town? I guess I told you or did I that last May,

a year ago, Charles & I had a chance to go to Hawai for 4 days. We spent much of the time with Frank Marshall Davis, who remembered you fondly and sent his regards. May I expect to hear from you?
Love --
Margaret

5/28/84
Dear Jack:
It was really great to see you on Conroy Day in Moberly.
You look simply great!
Stay Well,
Sincerely,
Margaret and Charles

pencilled in top margin  Burroughs, Margaret  [1984]
6/8/84
Dear Jack,

   It was really great to see you the other week.  Also to see the watercolor painting of ?the? old woman.  Speaking of the painting, it was done in 1947 and I have been invited to be in a show in Los Angeles, California of things that I did in the 40's.
   So, I am wondering if you will lend me this painting to put in the show.   It will be insured and it will be returned.  Perhaps you could have it packed and sent to

me by Greyhound Bus. 
I do hope you will & lend me the piece. 
The show opens July 1 and runs for two months. 
Stay well.
I wait to hear from you.
Sincerely,
Margaret

typed in top margin Margaret Burroughs to Conroy, 8-2-87
8/2
Dear Jack:
Charlie and I are still kicking around here - not too high. 
So many of our friends have passed over to the other side,
Ed, Joyce, etc. Just recently heard that Frank M Davis 
had the nerve to check

out. Can you imagine it - just after I brought out his book of poems too. 
Glad to hear that "ole Jack is hanging on." Drop a line when you can. 
Sincerely with Love, 
Margaret & Charlie

406 S Randolph
Champaign, Ill. August 12, 1945
Dear Jack:
Glad to hear from you. I've wanted to look you up in Chicago more than once but it didn't seem easy to find you. Next time I get up I'll give you a ring.
I haven't seen Sullivan nor heard from him for almost a year, but he probably still lives at the same place -- 4061 Blaine.  Give him my best when you see him. Maybe I can get down there myself before too long. By the way, if he's moved you'll be able to find him through his mother, Mrs. Frank? Soto, who has a phone (I believe).
I read your reviews in the Sun and I also noticed somewhere recently that you're going to be connected with a Chicago version of the New Yorker.  I'm going to look up your new book -- I haven't seen it yet. I'll be glad to recommend it for the library here if they haven't bought it yet, and to talk it up.
Tell Crenshaw to get the hell on the ball or I'll beat him into print. Two other guys and I are writing a college composition textbook which is pretty far along now. We're hoping to benefit by the pickup in college attendance that's going to come about in the next 2 or 3 years.
Heard about that encyclopedia a while back but didn't know you were one of the editors. It does seem to be a good thing. Regards, John Bushman

[handwritten above letterhead: Bushman, John [1958]
508 N. Pasqual
San Gabriel, Calif.
[Letterhead:] Los Angeles State College of Applied Arts and Sciences 5280 Gravois Avenue Los Angeles 32, California
Dec 22, 1958
Dear Jack,
I was sorry to learn that you have had further family troubles -- that you lost your son-in-law (I knew that Tommy died) -- but it was good to hear from you just the same. A lot of time has passed, hasn't it?
You seem to have a lot of zest still, I'm glad to note. As for me, I've become so draggy and lazy I'm not worth much -- and this at a time when everything else is in very nice shape. What I need is a long stretch of damn little work, and that's just what is coming up for me. I managed to get appointed Fulbright lecturer in American literature in Buenos Aires for 1959 and have taken a year's leave. Betty and Lynn (the younger daughter) are going too, and we're having lots of fun getting
(OVER)

ready for the big adventure.   We'll fly down on Argentine Airlines from New York and are planning some exciting stops - like Trinidad and Rio.  We're going to do a lot of visiting in the Middle west when we get back in November, and if we get to Chicago, will certainly look you up.

  I think I heard that you are a grandfather.  Well, I've been one for 6 months.  Luan married a local Mexican-American boy.   They live out near us and he works on my campus as a campus cop.  Which makes everything cozy.  I must say I don't feel very grandfatherly, and judging from the leaflet in your letter and your zippy comments I take it you don't either.
  I saw your Midland Humor anthology when it came out and enjoyed it.   Some day I'll look up your juveniles.  Probably the kids have read one or more of them without knowing their father knew the author.
  this sentence and following are completed in the left margin Sullivan has a gorgeous house in the suburbs, I hear, and as you might expect is the life of the party with his new friends.  (So   ?Mary? reports.)  Have a good holiday period.  Hello to Gladys.  John Bushman

pencilled in top marginJohn Bushman

January 9, 1959.
Hi Jack, 

I wanted to get a few lines to you before we leave next week. We are going cross country first, to fly to Buenos Aires from New York, and are stopping first in St. Louis, where we'll be guests over the weekend of Squire and Mrs. H. Sullivan. I must give you his address before I forget: 10730 Vorhof Dr, St Louis 21, Mo. 
There we expect to have an oldtime reunion. We'll make old Sullivan admire all our maps and time tables, and we'll ogle his spanking new all- airconditioned suburban dream home - and meet his new suburban Republican friends. Ha. I hear he's one of the boys with them. I'll have to see to that. 
I'd sure like a copy of Midland Humor, but don't send it to B. A. unless shipping it won't cost much - wait till I get back. I'll give you my address down there, though: Bushman, c/o Commission for Educational Exchange Between

U.S. and Argentina, Cerrito 550, Buenos Aires. The Commission is part of the US Embassy there but has an address of its own
because the exchange of students and teachers between the two countries is evidently a pretty big thing. Will take your address
along and send you a gaudy postcard. 
Happy to see you know some Español - hope you learned it the only sure and lasting way, from a sympatica amiga. 
Adios,
old Juan Bushman
I appreciate the tracts you've been sending, especially the ones on self-abuse. I'll distribute them on campus.
We have lots of youths with the symptoms described - loss of memory, dizziness, "strangeness of manner and crankiness." 
It will help them to know the source of their ailments.

letterhead  CALIFORNIA STATE COLLEGE AT LOS ANGELES 5151 State College Drive, Los Angeles, California  90032  (San Bernardino and Long Beach Freeways Interchange)  Department of English  Telephone 224-3722
April 4, '69
Dear Jack,
My wife doesn't take very good pictures, but here is a memento of our visit of last September, anyway.
Regards to Gladys 
Hope you are both well and enjoying the old home town.
John Bushman

Image on postcard
St. Paul's Cathedral, London.     Color Photo by John Hinde, F.R.P.S.

Dear Jack and Alice:
We thought this was a proper picture for the                                                
Rev. Conroy.                                                                                          
8 fine days in Europe so far - London,                                                     
Holland, now Belgium.                                                                           
Going back for more of London!                                                             
Best to you.                                                                                           
John and Betty Bushman
AIR MAIL  CONROY
CONROY
701 FISK AVE.
MOBERLY,
MISSOURI
U.S.A
SUMMER '69

File:Front of Christmas card with decorated tree and Santa Mouse
HO
HO
CHEERS

Phone call from our friend Sullivan recently. 
He's still working at the atomic plant making
those big union wages (with overtime). We knew him when

Dear Jack,

  There was real enthusiasm in our English Dept over the prospect of your coming to lecture but the dough situation interfered. The relevant committee didn't have money for anybody. There has been all-round crisis here. 
  Staying home this winter-holidays with the kids and grand-children. Look forward to reading autobiog installment JPopCult

printed message on Christmas card   WISHING YOU A HOUSEFUL OF HOLIDAY HAPPINESS
All the best to you and Gladys
John + Betty Bushman

Aug 11 Aug 5 is crossed out
Dear Jack,
Delighted to hear from you again, and I wish I had your card at hand, but Betty went through the joint house-cleaning in the last couple of days (she uses one of the county's street sweepers for the purpose), and your card got temporarily lost. (She says she'll find it again.) Anyway, glad to hear you may be out here -- with Gladys I hope.  Whether one or two Conroys, we'd like you to be our guests. We could squire you around to some points of interest. Some danger we may not be here because I'm off duty the Fall quarter, but let me know what develops.
You will be interested to learn that Betty
OVER

and I spent 3 weeks in June and July with the Sullivans in their new place in Ft Pierce, Florida. They bought an old house 1/2 block from the beach and fixed it up very pretty. They've got a lovely lot with all kinds of tropical stuff growing on it and a "Florida room" (all windows on 3 sides) from which you get a fine view of the Atlantic Ocean. Didn't think the Duke could be so handy at household repairs and beautification. Course Mary had a big hand in all of it. I like to think she told him what to do. They've got miles of fine wide beach in front them, not much developed along there.
Betty sends greetings to you and Gladys, as do I. Here's to old Chicago!
John Bushman
I hear Russell Finch moved to the San Diego area.  Never did find your card again.
[in left margin]:  If you give a talk out here at an area school we might be able to arrange, if you are interested, a talk at our school too -- for moderate pay.
pencilled in bottom right      [1971?]

typed in top margin  From Caldwell when he sent me his story to be in III. Return.
10/7/33
Dear Jack - Here is a story called Daughter for you to give the acid test. best wishes ?
N-B- I'm sure you are tickled to death with the new editor of The Mercury. Mike Gale got my ?date? just as I was thrown out of meeting -

Mount Vernon, Maine 
April 5th, 1933.
Dear Conroy -

I'm having to use a pen - typewriter Broken down today. Hope you can decipher this scrawl. That's dandy news about your Book. I knew ?Lieber? could sell it if anyone could - When will it be published. This fall I suppose. Let me  know if I can be of any help. I'ld like to do all I can.  I don't know if a word from me would help any, but if you thought so, I'd like to. I don't know so much about "sex" myself - publisher's "sex" is, to my way of thinking, a lot of hooey - Do you have a recent issue of the Anvil now? Or is it started yet. I'd like to beat you out of a copy some way. Right now I haven't a thing to send - but there's a long way to go yet. maybe soon - Best wishes - Sincerely ?Ernestine?

Image half-circle with rainbow-colored stripes
>2<
in China great respect is given to the over-80-tourists I think we should organize a tour group of writers that age so that they can be indulged in Chinese admiration as a tonic!

 It must be dreadfully lonely for you with your wife and pet both "walking in the heavens". If we're ever near Moberly we'll get in touch, and if you come to Arizona we want to see you -

Cordially,
Virginia

P.S.   My father was a Seventh Day Adventist minister. Mother died the day after their 60th anniversary. A year later at age 881/2 Daddy re-married a lovely 65 year old. He lived to be 97 and spent those latter years calling on the sick and the "old people," bringing a lot of joy to them because he remained young at heart. I like to share this experience because it is a cheerful one - it gives me a certain hope, and others, too. 
September 27, 1983
Dear Jack Conroy -
Thank you for your letter to Erskine for the birthday book. He is going to be so very glad to hear from you that I wish I could give it to him right away - but December is coming fast and he can enjoy it then.
Since we understand that
OVER please
"Caldwell, Erskine" is written in pencil along right margin.

pencilled in upper right margin  [1973]
letterhead    memo from Stivers Lifesavers
7 So. Dearborn St.
Chicago, Ill. 60614
Dear Jack -
In all the excitement at the autographing party I neglected to get my own copy signed!
Please do - and return to above address (My office) since I will be in Mexico right after Christmas.
Love to you and Gladys
Betty Campbell

Campbell, Effie (in pencil, at top right corner)
1/19/50
Dear Jack,
It doesn't appear - at the moment - that I can attend the affair for Will Wharton. Some in-laws from Wisconsin are spending the week-end in town.

  However -  I hope a lot of people can attend - and just as many buy a copy of his book. I am enclosing a check to cover the cost of a copy for myself - plus a little for postage.

Now - I may be able to attend and will bring a friend - if I can make it.
Think your invitation

-2-
is a work of art - You shouldn't have apologized - I am not prudish - my "looks" deceive.

  All the tickets for that luncheon at the Blackstone were sold - when I called.

See you around some day
Effie Campbell ?Schraeder?

Postmark BRITISH COLUMBIA  AUG 25 9 [?]M 
Aug 23-48
We came up here by boat today - "swell" trip and a beautiful city. Expect to be in San Francisco next week, best regards
Effie Campbell
Jack Conroy
130 N. Wells St
Chicago, IL
Room 1005

CAPLAN
Kansas City, Mo.
Nov. 26, 1933
Dear Jack:

  You can't imagine how all the comrades in town are whooped up about "The Disinherited."  We've had a battle with an old battle-ax of the Carrie Nation school, in the public library.  This bitch O.K's the books for the "institution" and your novel was on the taboo list, with a couple of big X's marked against it.  Well your old bud and his pals are making life miserable for them; your book - and they will have to buy a couple to meet the demand.  Birkenhead and Jenkins also going to the front for you.
  Mr. Birkhead was unable to procure a book, so the radio review will be laid over a week (Wednesday Dec. 6 3:30 P.M.).  this is no baloney - the liberals are in this "united front" strong; and your work will be the main Sunday topic, too, from more than one pulpit.
  Covici, Friede have a golden opporotunity sic in "The Disinherited," I believe.  An 'ad' in The Star  on a Sat. - about eight weeks in a row - would net them a barrel of dough.  This goddam agency of the Inquisition

letterhead  University of Missouri at Kansas City  Kansas City, Missouri  64110  THE UNIVERSITY REVIEW  Office of the Editor
Oxford Hale 6
March 15, 1969
Dear Jack Conroy,
Thank you for your kind words about our Review. I should have written sooner. We have piles and piles of manuscript that require constant attention. I hope that we shall have an opportunity to meet one of these days. I remember that Frances spoke of you when she worked editing The Chicago Library Bulletin, and she wished to put a good deal that could be of value in that profile that she wrote of you. She was then completing her B.A. or M. A. at the University of Chicago in the field of psychology although she also loved writing. She later taught psychology in Boston University and elsewhere. Thank you for your word about the stories -- that is, in saying that they were all

notable (Autumn, 1968) you have said a thing that is exceedingly encouraging to the authors, and to the editor, and the word about James Birney's "Night of Love" hits just the right point about the story; at any rate, I had this very thing in mind about it, and I hoped that others would feel it. 
It is a help to us to have the Review and its authors receive mention in the paper. It has at times been an acute problem to keep the magazine going at all, but now it has won its way and is not in as shaky circumstances as it often was formerly. We still rely a great deal on voluntary help in bringing out the Review --  help by people who have heavy full-time other duties.. and we get behind in our schedule.
Best wishes to you.
Cordially, Alex Cappon

Mr. Conroy, 
Many thanks for the interview. I like this feature above any I've done before. I hope you like it, too. 
I used information from the interview and from our meeting in July of 1983. If anything is wrong, I apologize. I tried hard to make everything just right. 
Best, 
Russ Cardwell

Mr. Conroy, 
Congratulations on the article on you in the Columbia Tribune and the publication of The Weed King and Other Stories. My editor (Jefferson City News + Tribune) and I are interested in doing a feature on you for our newspaper. I can come to Moberly and interview you at your convenience - if you are interested. 
Thanks. 
your friend in J.C. 
Russ Cardwell

[pencilled in top margin]  ca. 1986
Mr. Conroy, 
Happy birthday, and many more. I have the press plate, a photo and a couple of extra copies of your feature. I will be sending them by United Parcel in a few days. 
Best wishes, 
Russ Cardwell

postcard   postmark   LONDON  W.C.  6 15 PM 17 JLY 1966

Dear Jack--
The Bobbie on duty in Parliament prevented me from sitting where Sir Winston had sat (and Jack Conroy!) but I did park my butt briefly on the red leather of The House of Lords.
My claim to fame.
Thine,
Art Carlbom
Jack Conroy
7027 S Jeffery Blvd. 
Chicago, 
Illinois 60649
USA

Postmark PADDINGTON  12 45 PM 8 OCT 1969
10/8/69
Dear Jack + Gladys
Love London As you said, the most exciting city. Would live here if we could afford it. 
Otherwise, back to Spain where we live on the Costa del Sol. 
Will send our address on Christmas card. 
Be brave. 
Art Carlbom
Jack Conroy, Esq. 
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, 
Missouri 65270
U.S. of A.
Air Mail

Art Carlbone
Villa Nena
Calle del Mar
Fuengirola (Malaga)
Espana
Mr + Mrs Jack Conroy 
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri 65270
USA 
Correo Aereo

Fuengirola, Spain
Dear Jack + Gladys - 
Another year older + deeper in the expatriate bag. But wot's an aging lover going to do now in those feerooshus United States?
Better I stay here + wish all ye brave people a good Christmas + a fine new year.
Thine,
Art + Audrey Carlbom

clipping of printed article
Welcome, Art Carlbom
"WE HAVE too many columns already," is the editor's bleat when approached by another nascent Herb Caen.  But it was a different story when Art Carlbom tapped on the window.

  Carlbom, who has been writing for another Marin paper, said he liked the style of the Sun and wanted to be associate with it.  We are delighted.  Carlbom is surely the best columnist in Marin and one of the best around.   His approach is folksy, but there's a lot of keen insight at work.
  His column on the Hippies was a classic.  He wandered into the Hashbury, checked the action and decided that in the main Hippies were a lot of young people having a good time and putting on their elders.  Said Carlbom: Anytime a man in his circled word 50's gets all worked up over young people having a good time, then he is in trouble.
  Carlbom joins us in this week's issue, making the Sunshine even stronger.

Pacific Sun
[hand-written note at bottom of clipping]]
O
I sy, wot, and me still in me forties!   Art

Jack,
I thought you might like to see this card. We are now living in Girard at 516 N. Summit

Jack Conroy
Moberly, Missouri

Aug. 13 '32
Dear Jack:

     Once you promised to have a monument set up for me on the Red Square in Moscow.  I think I gave you enough time to do it in, so I'm going over in a couple weeks to see if the damn thing is there.  You bastards are so unreliable . . . .
  In fact I'm now in the passport-packing stage and all set for a stay of 6 months to a year and who knows . . . maybe I'll have a job fine combing for all the deviations you guys commit, reporting your virtues, etc.  At any rate, you'll hear from me as soon as I get there.  And meanwhile you might drop me a line here at my humble alley home?  Tellling me...
  What is the status of Rebel Poets, membership, etc.?  Give me a brief lineup on it will you?  I'll be grateful.
  You know just about what's been happening to me for the last 6 months.  Most of the time I've been out of shape and I havent had a thing to do with a single issue of N.M. since the February number.   There have been changes there aplenty and they are also having financial blues.  But that's not unusual and I'm sure they'll find some way around it.   The sheet, of course, has changed in character a

2
good deal.  How do you like it, Jack?

  Did you see the first number of "International Literature" - and the long and not so hot analysis of New Masses for 1931.  It's based on a resolution of the Bureau which is based on a resolution accepted by the NY JR Club which I wrote last winter.  I understand a handsome 22 year old female critic wrote the article so naturally I'll have to have a long discussion of it with her.  My interest in literary criticism grows daily . . .
  I liked your last Merc story tho not as well as "Boyhood" or "The Hard Winter" or "Paving Gang".  What are you doing now and how is the book coming on?   You shouldn't let up on it if you can help.
  What news have you of Humpy, Joe Kalar, Weiss, etc?  I've been away from things for a while and I'm curious, especially since I don't see much in recent issues of N.M.  Joe K. hasn't been producing for a helluva while and I wonder.  He's one guy who shouldn't let up.  Too valuable.
   Let's have word from you.   Regards.

Walt Carmon

1 Stuyvesant Alley, NYC.

Newspaper clipping;  Hemorrhoids New Way Without Surgery Stops Itch -- Relieves Pain]] 
Friday 2/1
Jack,

I was just finishing lunch + ready to head for the library when the mailman banged on the door with your book + World Progress. Breathlessly, all I can say is "I kees you Amigo."!
     I was on the point of putting in an order for this very book -- or putting up the dough to buy it. I am grateful as all hell and Rose and I are suckers for the mag. you get out. 

Just finished Upton Sinclair's autobiog and Ilya Ehrenburg's "People + Life 1891-1921." Sinclair's a prize rear end but an honest one and with more than a helluva lot to his credit despite what we (and I) thought of him. I enjoyed + learned a lot reading it. I'm happy to see he didn't mention Morrie Loeb + me when we were doing the Daily in Chicago in the early 20s when we serialized one of his novels. I wish I had kept the letters. He fumed because we short-changed him about 300 bucks. We just couldn't (over)

2/ 
get it up!  Cripes we weren't eating either.  Not regular..nor high on the hog.

  The Ehrenburg book I liked a lot.   The guy has a generous, pleasant attitude about people I like and it took guts to write it for Soviet publication.  He would have been castrated a few years earlier.
  The book you sent me follows "what comes naturally."  I'll read it soon, gladly.  May even tell you an humble opinion.
  Meanwhile look at the ?subservise? books ahead of me:

The Shark + the Sardines - Arevalo
Te Hundred Dollar Misunderstanding - Glover
Brendan Behan's Island - The Old Soak + lodge meister}

  If I don't end up on the lower level of hell despite the holy water of my bishop, its because the Reds fell down on the job.  Hoping you are the same & remember us to the very nice gal.

Rose & Walt
- and repeated thanks a helluva lot.
pencilled in right margin:   [1960's ?]
written in left margin
Have taken ?inserts? to heart.  Will abstain from sin.

Nov 8-
Benevolent Jack:
Received your elevating card and rushed to the nearest tavern to pray for you and to "listen to sweet Seraphim". I figured you had listened "to angels' songs, too".
You must be a mind reader. I did "worry of false unclear slipping and irritating". And godamnit they charged me enough unclear to send me home crying in my beer. Of course I slipped on the way a couple times to wipe my tears - or something spiritually. I was in shock.
I know the unclear Council is meeting in Rome but I must remind you of a nearing Xmas. I send suggestions. 
Your humble laborer in the vineyard
Sleeping Jesus
image

Thanks Conray:
And we dont care if you don't believe us: we want to see more from you on occasion. Regard.
P.S. Anything for us on Mark Twain?

[postcard]  
July 15 - 35
Murmansk Beyond the Polar Circle
250 miles above arctic circle
Believe it or not Jack this is a scene from a reindeer Kholkoz.  Here on a 12 day trip from Moscow - through White Sea Baltic Canal.  Swell all the way and interesting as all hell.
113 students and factory udarniks with us on the boat (S.S. Karl Marx) down the canal, singing, raising hell.  Oh what at ?tough? country this is!  You ought to see the grub we put away and what they wash it down with!  Come over.   Walt Carmon
Russian for USA   САШ 
Jack Conroy RR 4 Moberly, Mo. USA

August 12-'35
Dear Jack:
I smoked all the good cigarettes and here's the lid of the box. Reading: "To the Delegates of the 7th Congress of the Commin Era" -Bottom. in four lingoes - the first part of the title of your book which I HAVEN'T GOT. I read that you are going places. Get smacked down? For not sending the book. You deserve it. Getting piles?. Hoping you are the same Walt.

pencilled in top margin   Carmon, Walt
1/14/57
Dear Jack,
It was your religious tracts - and that classic poem "Suggestions for Parents of Children, etc" which were uppermost in my mind when the doctors dug deep into me and cut out a quarter-sized ulcer and surrounding tissue ( the gaza strip). And it was this bit of monkey business on the part of the medicos (bless 'em and g.d. their bills) that kept me from sending you greetings and advice for that hangover during the holidays. I was in the Lying-In Hospital 5 weeks to have this excuse for not writing you. 

 Meanwhile my long-suffering wife went out and got herself a batch of virus bugs that flattened her over the holidays.  So don't argue - I know there is a Santa Claus.  
 Some good friends came to visit (Bob Brown, Geo Redfield, Langston Hughes sent his latest book and cigarettes most of which the doctors swiped, Bob Lorenz and Amon Hennacy of

2/
The Catholic Worker who brought his autobiog. titled "The Autobiography of a Catholic Anarchist" and inscribed - so help me! - "To Wally Carmon In Christ the Rebel." He also brought a single rose on each visit. Dorothy Day, editor of the Catholic Worker also came (An old friend since the 20's in Chicago - when she was far from Catholic and wrote "The Eleventh Virgin".) So you see the Godly company I keep. That doesn't include Geo Redfield and the Bobs Lorenz and Brown. They're heathens. So is Hughes: he wrote "Goodbye Christ! remember? 

 But I'm feeling stronger and better everyday in every way etc. ?Love.? Today, after a look and change of bandages the saw-bones assured me that 2 more visits and he was rid of me. 
 And that's about it. For the next 6 months I'll have to celibate, Y.M.C.A-like, not look upon the grape when it is red, so holy I'll stink. 
 Hoping you are the same, Walt Carmon

Xmas Day
1961
Dear Jack:

  Were you ever taken aback while in a quandary?   That's what happened t me when your book arrived.  Literally, it caught me with my mouth open and my pants down.   Need I say merci beaucoup?  (My French stinks)  It was nice of you to think of me but eventually I would have got to the book even if it came to an extreme case of having to buy it.  The "internecine struggles" you suggest I clear up is a long old story, dead now as King Tut and amounting to archeological data.  After I read "Writers On the Left" I may relent a bit.
   Right now I'm reading the fantastic story of "The Black Muslims In America" by C. Eric Lincoln.
  Hoping you're not one of them, with repeated thanks for the book you sent & wishing both you heathens a Happy New Year so that Christian-Like you can go from scratch to a well deserved halo (look ma no commas - purr Faulkner)

Walt  pencilled in right margin:  Carmon
Added thanks for the Quarterly.

2/

 "We met Studs Terkel, one of their best radio interviewers...We saw Jack Conroy and invited him to the Goodman student show of "The Birthday Party" by Pinter.  He told us he saw you both about 3 years ago. - we are getting a copy of his Midwest Humor book"...
  I thought the first quote would do for the next edition?
  Read an item in Time that the editing couple who upped the circulation of the Ladies Home Journal in 29 years to 7,200,000 got fired because McCalls went to 7,400,000.  And you, brother Louse, want me to tell you what happened to me on the New Masses in 1932?  And how's  your circulation on World Progress?
  You owe me a letter, kind Sir, and may the birds never follow you and may the good St. Pat tell you what made him see snakes.

Walt
I told Max to be of good cheer.   I'd have a roast waiting for him with good brown gravy.   He accepted, claims he's only a Hygiene Fellow-Traveller.
A bow to the Lady.

2/8/62
Jack:
I finished "Left Writers" and found I was all in agreement on your estimate of the book. Just before the holidays Mike Gold returned from Mecca and in an interview he also found it a rant-free solid job but added -- gratuitously I think -- that it was "not Marxist Leninist."
Turning over the coin, you no doubt saw the full-page Time Mag. review saying : "A cool man Aaron spares his rod, excuses more than he accuses." Those boys want a slaughter of the Left and good RED meat (that's a pun, Son!) in pieces dripping with gore. Poor Aaron. When a perfessor [sic] nonchatontly [sic] strolls down the middle of the road, he's bound to get his pants full of buckshot in hunting season.
Just after I finished "Writers on the Left" (many thanks again, kind Sir) while browsing in the Library I chanced upon "The Radical Novel in the US" by Rideout, to which I see you have supplied data. His estimate of

2/
you as the most proletarian of the "proletarian writers" I cheered . . . with the reservation that old Karl himself didn't drive a truck.
But reading both books in succession left me with a cold realization all this happened over 30 Years ago! Cripes, it makes one feel decrepit doesn't it? I mean you, not me -- despite the purservatives [sic] we've enjoyed in our lives.
Maybe you know, but whatever in hell has ever happened to Norman Macleod? Is he alive yet? Poor guy, he thought Sandburg and Frost were squares. And Jimmie Farrell just told me over the phone that Mencken thought he (Farrell) was the greatest living writer in America. Ah, well! With a little of the juice . . .
Give our warmest regards to the Gal-in-charge and may your children never have dandruff.
Rose & Walt
PS. When your quarterly World Progress comes out of the printers, sneak a copy for us moochers? We're gluttons for well edited misinformation.

[pencilled in upper right corner: Oct 14, 1962]
Sunday 14
Dear Rabbi Jack:
Being fully conscious of the important meaning of Ecumenical Council, I swear to live right from now on: 

     and thank you with tears in me eyes for the gift of the Goldwater book, so nobly inscribed.  With Words, only one conscious of the Pope's message could have written! When the book arrived it literally caught me with my adjectives down. I could only gasp; now How did he know it was just what I wanted?

2 - Never reported on the Salisbury job: Despite argument on points, on the whole surprisingly good! This only on the political scene. For an authentic report on the people, peasant AND poet, Maurice Hindus' "House Without a Roof" best in recent years.
3 - Instead of spectaculars only, why doesn't radio give you a weekly turn. What the country needs is words of wisdom and in Missouri twang (since Harry's gone) Tell em one listener said so.
4 - Thanks for World Progress. Keep me on your list.
5 - Haven't read the China book yet -- just catching up after missing a month's reading, meanwhile the Ecum. Council AND WORLD SERIES and the Times. Remember (over)

2/
old home grounds are good if hectic to visit and who has time to read.

  You've just been to Missouri.
  And if this sounds hectic also, Ahm [sic] dogtired tonight and will add words again when & if something bright comes to me noggin.
  Thanks again, warm regards to all the Conroys, male & female

Rose & Walt, her sec'y
- cold War In the East -
newspaper clipping   The first shipment of Japanese "scotch" whisky is due in the U.S. soon.   Scotch distillers, said to be up in arms, are threatening to produce saki.

Dear Jack -

   Wally has been ill since August.   He has been wanting to write you, keeps mentioning it repeatedly but just hasn't the energy.  He suffers from complete nervous exhaustion, frustration because he is too weak to do the smallest taskes.   He is showing a bit of improvement, but it is slow.   Both of us pleased with your better health and envious of your energy.
  Best wishes to you and your wife -

Rose & Walt

Geo Redfield just called me mentioning that he had word from you.  So I thought an appropriate card - sort of symbolizing all us Lodge members would be in order.   How are you, you old Buzzard?   Here's hoping the stuff is never so bad you have to kill the taste by mixing.

pencilled in top margin  Corman, Walt [no date]
The Mrs. & Jack:

   I will heed the saintly admontions you included with your greetings.   That I swear.
   Like U-NW, Nehru and Poppe John SSIII, I will again, I swear (This time more loudly) to avoid cigarettes, wine and women.   I will not allow any of these vipers to enter my virgin breast.
   I know you and the Lady are past redemption.  though you may be lost souls, we send our greetings.  Bowing our heads for you in deep sorrow.

Penitently
Rose & Walt Carmon
Gladys: put a halter on him.
printed greeting on card:  WARMEST WISHES FOR A MERRY CHRISTMAS AND A HAPPY NEW YEAR * * * 
Remember - the way to perdition has often started with a small beer.  I read it in my bible.  W/

May 21 -
Jack, Old Fossil:

  I'm ever grateful for the book on China.   The last I read was by a Canadian (Scott?) and a reasonable job.  This book, unlike the dull British is by a free-swinging Australian - the highest recomend [sic] .  Will write you an honest and worthless opinion.
  Meanwhile Rose is having the time of her life with Salisbury's book on Mecca.  She keeps reading excerpts to me while I have my morning tea and crullers and they're good.  I mean excerpts.  Have glasses, will read.

Meanwhile I'm finishing Schweitzer on Africa and have Norris Houghton's "Return Engagement" which I'm anxious to read to remind me of Moscow vodka-breaks on the main stem called Gorky St. in my day.   Now its Iverskaya, like Broadway, only less expensive.  We've both been dipping into this one.  So far, good.

   Now a personal matter:  I don't mind being addressed as "Rev."  My Parochial school and Catholic Education (?) has sort of left me with a halo (aura? odor?) and a well deserved one.   But I protest bitterly against being called Walter.  That is my

(2
stage name.  If you call  Disney in your mag. Walter you'd not only be fired as senior Ed. but they wouldn't let a subsersive [sic] like you even sweep the office for fear you'd snoop in the wastbasket.  [sic]

  My true name is Ladislaus.  The Lithuanians who are  true descendents of the noble Mongols who went thru Asia like diarrhea, repeated over Europe and only were stopped by the Baltic.  A characteristic of even the Lets of today is they hate water, never use it, inside or out.   They use sand-paper.  But from their neigbors [sic] they got vodka.  While suffering a godawful hangover the Poles stepped in and my name, given us by Romans, was changed to Władysław (always with tilde!)  When the Lithuanians sobered up and clobbered the Poles, Ladislaus came back.  But the Russians brought over more vodka. and as you can see by the papers, the Lithuanians aren't sure its better or worse.  If ever you need any dope on Lithuanians you can get it straight from the Mongol horse's mouth, at only slightly higher than usual space rates.  Only rember [sic], never pull a rock by calling

3/
me Walter.  The dumb Poles who displaced the Indians around Chicago thought they Americanized Władysław calling him Walter, of ?Hitbrite? origin.

   So with this little sex lesson, and repeating thanks for the book.

The very Reverend Walt Carmon [drawing of a cross with lines around it]] Sunshine Mission or Ladislaus, the Mongol
-- With a courtly bow to the lady - may see you both come Sept. if we pass on our way to the Coast & Mexico - the good Lord and N.N. Lewis willing.

pencilled in upper margin  [Tim Carter]  [no date]
Jerry,
Well how in the hell are you? What have you been up to all summer? Got a job? What are you doing?
There really isn't a whole lot going on here right now, things are po kind of slow right now. We are in semester break right now so I've been enjoying just loafing around the last couple weeks. I've been studying quite a bit though because exams are after the break. Pretty fucked up, huh?
I don't know if you've met them of sic not but my brothers, Allen and  José are home now so there has been a little more to do with them.

  Things are really gonna be dull here after August. Allen and José are leaving and taking 2 of my best friends back with them. Also at the end of this month 3 other of my friends are leaving for school in Mexico. What the hell! I guess I'll just start catching up on my drinking. I've quit drinking beer! I have one every now and then but as far a sic drinking goes I've been hitting the Rum pretty hard.

it really is good here. I really getting kind of bored here and already counting the time before I'll be home. I'm ready for a good party, "Moberly Style." or just a night out with the boys, playing cards or baggin' beaver!
Well Jerry, I can't think of much more to write about so I'll be going. I havn't heard much from home so send me any hot news you can think of. Take care buddy and be ready to tie into a good one Christmas!
See ya soon
Timatéo

did Gold's work for him.  Both Mike and Walt must have some the blame for the impossible situation that followed.  I believe that the episode is about closed, and no good can come of prolonging the echoes

R. Chamier

1 July
Reverend and honored Elder Sage:
It seems you did better in your article than did Carl Erwin Sumpter.
I have no obsession with sex. Do you?
I can't really remember what sex is all about. Can you?
Do I understand the thrust of your remarks to indicate that bad financial times breeds more or less sex --- What ever that is?
A worshipper at you honored feet ---

Subject: Invitation To VIP For State Visit
TO:  VIP Conroy 9-14-67
FROM:  Eager Beaver Chamier
Ready now.
New furniture in place, waiting for inspection.
Old body quivering with excitement.
Coffee pot on.
How about it?
I've been wondering for 5 days why you ain't been here.
Then I noticed I hadnt mailed this thing - which ought to be taken as a fair reason, ought it not?

Written in pencil in upper margin:   Charmchi, Maryam   [1988]
Dec 29th
Dear Mr. Conroy
Hello. How are you? It seems that it was not long ago since I visited you at your house, but a year has gone by. I moved to Lawrence again Last April and have been extreemly [sic] busy with work, house and the family. However I have had many thoughts about you, your books and the impression they made on me. It has been so grand to know a truly free spirited person like you.   People such as yourself bring meaning to boring monotenous [sic] days. I missed your birthday, Christmas and I guess the New Year. But I told myself I should drop you a note and just see how are things with you, and also to let you know that I did not totally forget you.
Happy belated birthday, Christmas and the best wishes for the New Year.
take care
Sincerely
Maryam Charmchi

[sheet torn from a calendar dated February 1934]
Dear Joe: - 'Am sorry not finding you.  I just learned that your (Y) K.C. symposium will be held for the benefit of a degenerate Trozkyist outfit (Workers' Modern Library).  Please do not lend yourselves

[sheet torn from a calendar dated February 1934]
and CP and the A & W Union, or the principles you stand for, to anything like this.

  You must not make the trip.  Send a wire of cancellation.
  You may see me tonight at 5706/ a /Easton Ave (IWO Hall)
   Please do see me.

P. Chaunt
